title: How to tell the difference between a word used to describe tone and one used to describe mood - Quora

response.answer_text: It really depends on what you mean by “tone” and “mood.” See, in literature, we talk about tone as the writer’s attitude toward a subject and the mood as how we are “made to feel” as readers. Your question was: How do I tell the difference between a word used to describe tone and one used to describe mood? In this situation, you CAN’T. From the writer’s perspective, the only thing they can “technically” do is to write with whatever attitude, whatever opinion they have of the subject matter. They can’t write as anything other than themselves. Even if the writer wrote something because he was trying to make you feel a certain way, it would still be considered tone because he may not have succeeded. Essentially, the mood isn’t determined when the writer writes; it’s determined when the reader reads. That’s my take, anyway. It’s a very interesting question; thanks for requesting my answer. Good luck on your English endeavours!

Tone and mood are different things, but the same words can describe them. So it’s all about context. Tone comes from the writer, mood describes the reader. Whatever you’re reading, just remember: Tone went in, mood comes out. Sometimes, the same word can describe both. If someone is sad about what they’re writing about (their tone), hopefully they can convey that sadness to the reader (their mood).
